page.title: 06BUILDINGS at Blindcrake
page.content: During 1985 (and previous years) change has come to the village with the modernisation of the vernacular stone built cottages,farms and barns, the majority built in the period 1620 to 1780. Under the watchful eye of the Lake District Special Planning Board approval has been given for conver- sion, extension and building using local traditional materials. This year saw a Public Enquiry over planning permission for two of the few remaining possible building sites in the village. One was rejected, the other has many conditions attached if buiding is to take place. 1985 also saw the village enter the "Best kept small village" competition, We came second. The Ghyll Yeat pub has possibly the smallest bar in England-one tiny room!
